Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 27, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Bench  in Criminal Appeal No. 83 of 1963 and Criminal Reference No. 4 of 1963. K. Luthra, for the appellant.

RAGHUBAR DAYAL J.-Faddi appeals, by special leave, against the order of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh confirming his conviction and sentence of death under s. 302 I.P.C. by the Additional Sessions Judge, Morena.

witnesses Nos. 15, 4 and 5 respectively. The conviction of the appellant is based on circumstantial evidence, there being no direct evidence about his actually murdering Gulab by throwing him into the well or by murdering him first and then throwing the dead body into the well.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 defines an admission to be a statement, oral or documentary, which suggests any inference as to any fact in issue or relevant fact, and which is made by any of the persons, and under the circumstances, thereafter mentioned, in the Act. Section 21 provides that admissions are relevant and may be proved as against a person who makes them.

holdings.text: The High Court did not rely on the confession and recovery of shorts rightly

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did not rely on the confession and on the recovery of the pair of shorts from the appellants possession, and we think, rightly. The evidence about the confessions is discrepant and unconvincing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence on confessions discrepant and unconvincing; shorts recovery lacks proper identification and questioning

holdings.text: Section 25 of the Evidence Act and s. 162 CrPC do not bar admissibility of the FIR; it is an admission by the accused

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 of the Evidence Act and s. 162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure do not bar its admissibility. The report is an admission by the accused of certain facts which have a bearing on the question to be determined by the Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: FIR not confessional or statement during investigation; qualifies as admission under ss.17,21 Evidence Act provable against maker

holdings.text: The objection to the admissibility of the first information report lodged by the appellant is not sound and the Courts below have rightly admitted it in evidence and have made proper use of it

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the objection to the admissibility of the first information report lodged by the appellant is not sound and that the Courts below have rightly admitted it in evidence and have made proper use of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedents like Nisar Ali (confessional FIR); follows Dal Singh; FIR used to show false explanations as admission against interest

holdings.text: The circumstances held established by the High Court are sufficient to reach the conclusion that Gulab was murdered by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances held established by the High Court are sufficient, in our opinion, to reach the conclusion that Gulab was murdered by the appellant who was the last person in whose company the deceased was seen alive and who knew where the dead body lay

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chain of circumstances (last seen alive, failure to explain separation, prior knowledge of body location, false statements in FIR and court) unerringly points to guilt absent reasonable explanation
